headline: CES 2012: the key gadgets - in pictures
text: Motorola's Droid 4 smartphone on display Photograph: David Becker/Getty Images       Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer looks on during a presentation of his keynote address  Photograph: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images       Industry affiliates take photos of LG's new 55-inch Super OLED TV  Photograph: Julie Jacobson/AP       Bluetooth-enabled watches that connect to your smartphone on display from i'm watch of Italy  Photograph: Bruce Bennett/Getty Images       A Windows rep gives a demonstration of features available on the Lumia 800, Nokia's high-end Windows phone for the international market  Photograph: Frederic J Brown/AFP/Getty Images       A prototype Vaio tablet on display at the Sony booth  Photograph: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images       An artist uses Samsung's Galaxy Note Photograph: David Becker/Getty Images       The Swiss Army Knife from Victorinox, with a 128GB flash drive. It will be available with 64GB, 128GB, 256GB, 512GB and 1TB drives Photograph: Frederic J Brown/AFP/Getty Images       A smartphone sending instructions to a cooker using LG's newest Smart ThinQ technology is demonstrated  Photograph: Ethan Miller/Getty Images       A man checks out a Scion SD vehicle fitted out with a booming Scosche HD soundsystem  Photograph: Frederic J. Brown/AFP/Getty Images       Samsung TVs on display  Photograph: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images       Greg Pan, chief executive of Greenworld, puffs away on its recently introduced electronic cigarette  Photograph: Bruce Bennett/Getty Images       Phil Molyneux, president and chief operating officer of Sony, talks about the new foldable Tablet P during a news conference Photograph: Jack Dempsey/AP       Convention attendees inhale flavoured oxygen at the Air Head oxygen bar in the Motorola booth  Photograph: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images       A woman touches the screen on Sharp's 80-inch touchscreen TV set Aquos Board, an interactive display system Photograph: Frederic J Brown/AFP/Getty Images       Ultrabooks on display at the Intel stand Photograph: Julie Jacobson/AP       The Proton Semiconductor Sequencer from Ion Torrent Systems, a new DNA sequencing machine and chip designed to sequence the entire human genome in about eight hours displayed at the Life Technologies booth  Photograph: Ethan Miller/Getty Images
